content.question:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Polycystic kidney disease (<math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is an inherited disease that causes water loss from the body and affects cell division in the kidneys. Because water movement across cell membranes is related to ion movement, scientists investigated the role of the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>/K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext> ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (also known as the sodium/potassium pump) in this disease. Ouabain, a steroid hormone, binds to the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>/K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in plasma membranes. Individuals with <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> have a genetic mutation that results in an increased binding of ouabain to the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>/K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The scientists treated normal human kidney (<math alttext="N H K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NHK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells and <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with increasing concentrations of ouabain and measured the number of cells (Figure 1) and the activity of the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 2) after a period of time. The scientists hypothesized that a signal transduction pathway that includes the protein kinases <math alttext="M E K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MEK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="E R K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ERK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 3) may play a role in <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> symptoms.

Figure 1. Cell number compared with the number of cells at <math alttext="0 picomolar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>pM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ouabain. Normal human kidney (<math alttext="N H K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NHK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells and polycystic kidney disease (<math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells were treated with increasing concentrations of ouabain. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus, 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.
 Figure 2. Percent <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>/K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity of <math alttext="N H K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NHK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells treated with increasing concentrations of ouabain. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus, 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Figure 3. Signal transduction pathway hypothesized to play a role in the increased number of <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells

(a) Describe the characteristics of the plasma membrane that prevent simple diffusion of <math alttext="N a plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="K plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> across the membrane. Explain why <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is required for the activity of the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Polycystic kidney disease (<math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is an inherited disease that causes water loss from the body and affects cell division in the kidneys. Because water movement across cell membranes is related to ion movement, scientists investigated the role of the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>/K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext> ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (also known as the sodium/potassium pump) in this disease. Ouabain, a steroid hormone, binds to the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>/K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in plasma membranes. Individuals with <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> have a genetic mutation that results in an increased binding of ouabain to the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>/K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The scientists treated normal human kidney (<math alttext="N H K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NHK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells and <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with increasing concentrations of ouabain and measured the number of cells (Figure 1) and the activity of the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 2) after a period of time. The scientists hypothesized that a signal transduction pathway that includes the protein kinases <math alttext="M E K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MEK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="E R K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ERK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 3) may play a role in <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> symptoms.

Figure 1. Cell number compared with the number of cells at <math alttext="0 picomolar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>pM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ouabain. Normal human kidney (<math alttext="N H K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NHK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells and polycystic kidney disease (<math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells were treated with increasing concentrations of ouabain. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus, 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.
 Figure 2. Percent <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>/K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity of <math alttext="N H K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NHK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells treated with increasing concentrations of ouabain. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus, 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Figure 3. Signal transduction pathway hypothesized to play a role in the increased number of <math alttext="P K D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells

(a) Describe the characteristics of the plasma membrane that prevent simple diffusion of <math alttext="N a plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="K plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> across the membrane. Explain why <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is required for the activity of the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Identify a dependent variable in the experiment represented in Figure 1. Justify the use of normal human kidney (<math alttext="N H K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NHK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells as a control in the experiments. Justify the use of a range of ouabain concentrations in the experiment represented in Figure 1.

(c) Based on the data shown in Figure 2, describe the relationship between the concentration of ouabain and the <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mo>/</mo><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity both in normal human kidney (<math alttext="N H K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NHK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells AND in <math alttext="P K D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells. The scientists determined that <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity in <math alttext="P K D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells treated with <math alttext="1 picomolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>pM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ouabain is <math alttext="150" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>150</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> units of <math alttext="A T P hydrolyzed per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP hydrolyzed/sec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the expected <math alttext="N a plus, K plus, A T P ase" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity (<math alttext="units per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>units/sec</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) in <math alttext="P K D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells treated with <math alttext="10 to the sixth power, picomolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>pM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ouabain.

(d) In a third experiment, the scientists added an inhibitor of phosphorylated <math alttext="M E K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MEK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="lowercase p, M E K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pMEK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) to the <math alttext="P K D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells exposed to <math alttext="10 to the fourth power, picomolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>pM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ouabain. Based on Figure 3, predict the change in the relative ratio of <math alttext="E R K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ERK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="lowercase p, E R K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pERK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in ouabain-treated <math alttext="P K D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with the inhibitor compared with ouabain-treated <math alttext="P K D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells without the inhibitor. Provide reasoning to justify your prediction. Using the data in Figure 1 AND the signal transduction pathway represented in Figure 3, explain how the concentration of cyclin proteins may increase in <math alttext="P K D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells treated with <math alttext="10 to the fourth power, picomolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>pM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ouabain.
